title: Government jobs in creating technology, world analysis... etc..

content: There are numerous "Intel" jobs in all branches of the service. In the Air Force, there is an Enlisted AFSC called Intelligence Specialist. The individual goes to tech school to learn various skills dealing with classified information and giving briefings on such. It is a good position, usually in the Operations Section of a Squadron. The briefings are given directly to personnel dealing with all aspects of flying missions. You have to have a high school education, with good academic grades in the more rigorous classes of math, science, history, and writing. You also have to have a clean legal slate so that you can obtain at least a Secret Clearance. I'm certain, again, that all branches of service have jobs in Intelligence Gathering, Handling, and Dissemination. Good communication and computer skills would help greatly also... Which branch of service are you interested most in? Wandering and Wondering
reply: There are numerous "Intel" jobs in all branches of the service. In the Air Force, there is an Enlisted AFSC called Intelligence Specialist. title: Government jobs in creating technology, world analysis... etc..

content: Most devices are not created by the military The creation of devices, systems, and the like are by private companys. Sometimes the military will issue a list of requirements (for say an aircraft) Private companys will then design and build prototype aircraft for the military to approve and buy or reject and look at another design from another company. Sometimes if a company has a realy good idea they will build it and go to the military and say HAY LOOK AT THIS if the military likes it they buy it. In general this procedure is in effect thruout the military procurement process for all systems and devices. The realy highend technology is in the hands of civilian companys. The highend intel is gathered by machines provided by civilian companys Shockey
reply: Most devices are not created by the military The creation of devices, systems, and the like are by private companys. content: quote: Originally posted by 20907600: how would I get to a position of working on high end technology not yet implemented into society? Intellgience stuff, I'd like to join If I can make thing's. That's not intelligence stuff; it's engineer stuff. In a very simplified way, intel geeks find out what other guys are making. Counterintel folks prevent the other guys from finding out what we are making. The engineers are the folks who are doing the making. Enlisting isn't the only (or most direct) route to do this. We have lots of civilian engineers with clearances, both as defense contractors and government employees. Shockey is right that the contractors do the building, but also there are some army engineers who get into the muck of it as well, particularly when we need some problem solving, and they are of course heavily involved in field testing of new technology. As greywolfghost noted, you can figure on needing a clearance, either secret or higher, so you'd need a squeaky clean background to even be considered. Based on the politics expressed in your post, you might also look into foreign service if you aren't set on making things, and possibly also peace corps. I know less about peace corps, but if you are looking to help countries with food security that might be a good option - just stay away from the Monsanto crap, eh? That stuff isn't helping anyone in the long run. (Apologies for the editorial note there.)
